comment: Beats me how some people come to review products and claim that 32gb sdcard had only 29 gb space. how 64gb pen drive has 57 gb space. If you dont have technical knowledge, do your research and find out. Dont bring your ignorance to undermine good products because your brain is tiny. Every storage device has less capacity than advertised. This is because every storage device has to store some other identifying information which defines its own identity and the identity of its contents. Open your selfie phone when you pout on it and check its storage, then downvote it on commerce websites because you have an ignorant arrogant tiny brain.As far as this product is concerned, its value for money and works great. comment: I was earlier sent a fake card which I identified in 1 second.Then I ordered a replacement online through Amazon and now I finally got an ORIGINAL Samsung card.I've attached photos the real card's packaging, so you may decide wisely what card you're getting... If you feel something is wrong (detail not matching order, wrong fonts, bad quality print, etc.) return it by going to "My order" on Amazon and ask for original one immediately....The write speed, as guaranteed by U3 marking should be above 30MB/ second as per Memory card association.In my card it was claimed to be 90MB/ second on package, and 100MB/ second read speed.Of course, on an older system with no so accurate readers, you get around 20 MB/ second maximum. But on newer mobiles phones, you do get upto 60-90 MB/second or so.This card is good for phones supporting SDXC, and remember, it may also be supported on phones which claim to support much less.Example, My Redmi 2 Prime claimed to support only 32GB, and guess what, 64 and even 128 GB cards from both Samsung and Sandisk were supported and ran awesome!! Please remember SDXC standard supports very high capacities, maybe upto 512 GB. SDHC, an older standard supports only upto 32GB.Card was made in Phillipines. A useful SD adaptor (with a writing-lock switch) was supplied which was made in China.Capacity that came was 119GB, which is slightly more than 128,000,000,000 bytes.(The difference in capacity is due to 1024 bytes=1KB and 1024KB= 1MB and 1024 MB = 1GB).
title: Was sent a fake. Now all ok.

comment: First off the average user or photographer will have no trouble with this card, as it has great storage capacity. I've been using one for about a year now and it still performs well, although with a few hiccups here and there. However, this is not a fast card, and I cannot recommend it for any professional use. Using burst mode on my Nikon (shooting RAW) shows a considerable lag between the shots being taken and written to the card - so you'll be severely limited in your shooting capacity. It also takes a considerable amount of time to copy data on/off so the "100MB/s" sales pitch is just a gimmick.Occasionally, the card refuses to read on my camera, for no apparent reason.That being said this is a very affordable option for a bit of hobby photography or for storing your files, but I wouldn't trust its reliability and I certainly don't recommend it for professional work. Buy something like a Samsung Pro SDXC or PNY card for that instead.
title: Decent, but avoid for professional work

comment: The memory card worked fine for 8 months (October 2018- June 2019 ), after which I lost 28 gb data overnight, followed by the remaining 29 gb in the following 2 days (for which I had the foresight to take backup, thank God), and then the card got corrupted. I formatted it on my phone and started using it again, thinking all was well now. Well guess what, I lost all data AGAIN AFTER FORMATTING and the card again being shown "corrupted" on my phone. What use is a memory card if I have to take backup of everything I store on it ? If I had to take backup of my storage source (card) everytime I used it, wouldn't i just use the backup source as my primary storage instead ? Horrible product from Samsung that has managed to give me a new level of trust issues. I don't have the time nor energy to pursue the warranty which I'm expecting will turn out to be another scam on Samsung's part. Waste of time, waste of money and a new lesson in life: always take backup, especially while using sh*t products from Samsung.
title: Deception at its best- corrupted within 8 months, lost important data

comment: Both the 64GB memory card and adapter are in good condition. At Rs 699 got a substantial discount the MRP being Rs 1899. Recorded 4K UHD videos on my Asus Zenfone Max Pro M1. Could play it back without any lag. Copied to my old Windows 7 Lenovo Z580 laptop using the adapter in the microSD card slot. Could save the 4K file easily on the laptop. Tried the memory card + adapter in my DSLR Canon 1300 D. Saves pics fast and easy. Don't know whether it could record 4K UHD videos in the card as my DSLR does'nt have that high resolution. But the mobile does. 4KUHS 1 requires 4.2 gb for a 01 hr video and 4K UHD requires around 32 GB for the same duration. The microSD card has been manufactured in the Phillipines and has a 10 yr warranty. But the adapter is of Chinese make and has a warranty of only 01 yr. Edges of the microSD card are white. So its definitely an original Samsung one. It could be a good back up card for even professional photographers.

I also tested the 64 GB U3 variant and it showed a write speed in between 55 and 65 MB/s while copying to the card. So in my case, the 128 GB card showed good results. comment: Remember that in SD Cards, there are Classes and Grades and UHS I and II and... UGH!  Gets a bit crazy. I think right now Class V90 UHS II are fastest, but really even the UHS I cards are PLENTY fast enough unless you're recording 4K video or you're always copying gigs and gigs regularly... and they're much cheaper too!So... this card was exactly as described.  Comes with bigger SD adapter so you can use in PC or phone/tablet.  Tested it using some free tools and its speed is what it should be.  Of course you don't get the actual advertised capacity in ANY storage device you buy, which is ridiculous, but that's the way it is.Had a couple SanDisk cards and one failed after almost five years (which is not too bad)... thought I'd try Samsung this time since it is so well-rated.I will update my review if things change, but so far I'm happy with this card... have pounded it hard over the past couple days and it's doing great!  Doesn't get hot either.I think you will not be disappointed.  Thanks, and please click "Helpful" below...
title: Great!

comment: Got what I paid for. Samsung is a brand you can trust with memory, be it SSDs or memory cards.Using this card in my mobile, which formatted the card to be used as internal storage.So I am using this to mostly store apps.Read & Write speeds are best in class, and its a reliable memory card.fully satisfied.If you are confused between Sandisk Ultra vs Samsung,go with Samsung for the following reasons -1. This card came out later, which means it an updated model as compared to Sandisk ultra.2. Samsung is U3 Speed class which is faster than Sandisk's U1. (Don't confuse with UHS - 1 )3. Samsung 64 GB is 750Rs, Sandisk 64 Gb is 800Rs4. Sandisk Ultra card was released more than 10 years ago so it is optimized for Class 10 , where as Samsung EVO is UHS - 1, which is a more updated standard.5. Talking about A1 Speed certification, which is basically mobile Application write and read performance based on Random reads and write speeds, Even though Samsung lacks this and Sandisk ultra has an A1 certification, Check the Random read and write speed benchmarks done using the below links, Samsung speeds are beating the competition by miles.Benchmarks -samsung-evo-plus-microsd-review at hothardware dot comwiki/benchmarks/microsd-cards at pidramble dot comVerify your own Samsung SD card as genuine using Samsung's official software -just google Samsung sd card checker
